newsitem.title: GERMANY: Frankfurt bourse jumps higher after Clinton win.
newsitem.headline: Frankfurt bourse jumps higher after Clinton win.

text.p: The Frankfurt bourse opened sharply higher on Wednesday after Bill Clinton held onto the U.S. Presidency and the Republicans maintained control of Congress, a combination markets saw as optimal.
Overnight gains on Wall Street, which ended up 39.50 points at 6,081 points, a firmer dollar above 1.52 marks and continuing German bond strength also helped market sentiment.
The DAX index of 30 leading shares, was up 32.19 points, or 1.20 percent, at 2,723.48 in early trade, but off day highs and below the all-time bourse high of 2,739.26 hit on October 18.
Although the U.S. election results provided the morning's main focus, the market was also kept busy digesting a barrage of company figures and news.
Chemical company Hoechst rose 1.75 pfennigs, or over three percent, to 59.58 points, after the company announced nine month results.

Preference shares in business software group SAP AG gained the most ground amongst the DAX stocks, continuing to recover from the blow of a profit warning two weeks ago. SAP preference shares were up over four percent, or eight marks, at 204 marks.
Industrial group Daimler Benz also climbed strongly, after a newsletter said the firm was due to report nine-month turnover growth of 10 percent on Thursday.
Truck manafacturing and engineering group MAN AG was down over two percent or eight marks at 366.00 marks after the firm announced a rise in July to September sales.
Electronics firm Siemens, due to issue provisional 1995/96 results later in the day, was up 64 pfennigs at 80.00 marks.
Continuing weaker against the market trend was Germany's largest bank Deutsche Bank, which traded up three pfennigs at 69.80 marks, but below the crucial 70 mark level.
